bibl.title: The Roman 'Carrot' Amphora and Its Egyptian Provenance.
bibl.note: Publication of an inscription - koÊk(ia) - painted on a sherd of a Roman 'carrot' amphora found at Carlisle in a late-Flavian context. Its apparent reference to the fruit of the doum palm suggests that this class of amphora was made in Egypt and was used to export Egyptian preserved fruit. - Description of the fruit. - The words koÊkion and kÒÛj in papyri of the Roman period. <kouk(ia), koukion, koïx>
bibl.seg: TOMLIN R.S.O., The Roman 'Carrot' Amphora and Its Egyptian Provenance.
JEA 78 (1992) pp. 307-312, 1 fac-sim. et pl. XXXIII, 4.
